title: what's up, the name's amri.
body:
ok not really, but thatâ€™s what iâ€™m going as.

if this is the first time coming across my profile, iâ€™m an artist/engineer/streetwear designer + this is my first attempt at combining everything iâ€™ve worked on in my life into a single stream of consciousness. 

iâ€™m currently in the middle of launching my second NFT project as an artist, but iâ€™ve done a bunch more art throughout my life and have been creating for my streetwear brand since 2018.

my whole life iâ€™ve been trying to figure out the best channel to go down in order to share my art with the world. i discovered nfts in january 2021, and have been working as an engineer in the space while doing side projects for my creative expression. thereâ€™s been a lot of noise iâ€™ve had to navigate and iâ€™ve been figuring things out along the way. i worked on my first nft project last year for 5 months and built the whole thing myself, which was one of the most rewarding experiences in my career. even though only \~3% of the nfts got minted, the process taught me a lot about what i was able to create if i put myself into my work. 

since then iâ€™ve switched jobs and have started working on a new project in my spare time, bc i donâ€™t want to stop creating. iâ€™ve let go of a lot of the fluff i had in mind the first time around, and am taking this shit less seriously now. motorheadz will be free art for those visually interested in my work and mark the beginning of a new personal journey for me. i want to begin to allow myself to freely create art without trying to tailor anything to anyone. this is what makes me happiest, and is the only way that i can look back at my work and be proud of what iâ€™m doing. 

after i finish this motorheadz mint iâ€™m embarking on a journey to build out the world that has always existed in my head. iâ€™m forever grateful to everyone whoâ€™s supported me on my journey til now-- yâ€™all are who i create for and the support is what keeps me motivated.

title: Quest for a lost Event
body:
The last time I wrote about [Ethereum logs](https://codeburst.io/deep-dive-into-ethereum-logs-a8d2047c7371) was in 2018. This time we go deeper and try to recover a ghost event that devs have forgotten to add to the Yearn Vaults contract.

```
log Fees(management_fee, performance_fee, strategist_fee)
```

There are several methods to recover values from an internal view method or even add custom views to batch read private storage. One of the more interesting ones is a â€œ[state override](https://www.libevm.com/2022/01/12/advance-geth-pt-2-stateoverrides/)â€ option of `eth_call`, which allows you to replace the code and storage for the context of the call.

To my deep disappointment, you canâ€™t just set a breakpoint on a line you want, start a debugger to capture the local variables, and call it a day. This may change soon with a [Vyper interpreter](https://github.com/vyperlang/titanoboa) being in the works.

This post will describe a method based on capturing the values from a trace frame. The values we are interested in should appear on the stack or in the memory [around this line](https://github.com/yearn/yearn-vaults/blob/v0.4.3/contracts/Vault.vy#L1621).

## Obtain Vyper metadata

The `debug_traceTransaction` method gives us trace frames with opcode-level resolution. To find the correct trace frame, we need to find the program counter around the end of `_assessFees` method execution. Maybe the metadata Vyper compiler generates could help us do that:

```
vyper -f source_map contracts/Vault.vy > source_map.json
```

The source map contains `pc_jump_map` and `pc_pos_map`, which looks promising. The jump map contains values of `i`, `o`, `-`, which seem to stand for jump in, jump out, and jump umm. Intuitively we want to find the jump out of the function, but it wonâ€™t be there since itâ€™s the last internal method in the contract.

The position map is formatted as `start_line`, `start_col`, `end_line`, `end_col` for each program counter. This could help us limit the search window to the desired function. The simplest way to find the line numbers is to just look at the source file, but there are a dozen of Vault releases, and we want to automate the search as much as possible. Getting more metadata from the compiler wouldnâ€™t hurt:

```
vyper -f ast contracts/Vault.vy > ast.json
```

This format outputs the abstract syntax tree of the parsed contract, which looks the same as Python ast. We can find all the definitions in the ast body, and find the function by name:

```
fn = next(item for item in ast["ast"]["body"] if item.get("name") == "_assessFees")
```

The definition would contain `lineno` and `end_lineno`, which is exactly what we need to scale the search to all versions. Now we can output all the program counters which have originated from a line range in the source and exist in the jump table.

They will also come in handy later when we need to deal with edge cases.

## Rewrite in Python

After writing a script that checks out all Vault releases from git tags and compiles them, we have enough metadata to start the search. But we still donâ€™t have the concrete values to match on. Luckily itâ€™s easy to convert Vyper to Python. You just rename the file.

Yearn Vaults also behave according to their `apiVersion`, so we can write a universal `_assessFees` function, which was an interesting enough [exercise on its own](https://github.com/banteg/yearn-fees/blob/master/yearn_fees/assess.py). Even if it doesnâ€™t handle all the edge cases yet, it works well enough to provide us with the calculated values to look for in a trace.

## Look at the trace

> Tip: If you often work with Ethereum traces in Python, consider looking at [evm-trace](https://github.com/apeworx/evm-trace), it can parse both Geth- (opcode-level) and Parity-style (call-level) traces, turn them into a call tree, and display them to your liking via a custom display class.

A trace frame at the program counter we found contains all the values we need both on the stack and in memory, so Iâ€™ve hidden the memory part below and annotated the values I could identify on the stack.

```
{
    'pc': 21139,
    'op': 'JUMP',
    'gas': 1749825,
    'gasCost': 8,
    'depth': 7,
    'stack': [
        '0xa1d9bafc',
        '0x70a08231',
        '0x564bf2844654f149821697cc56572ee4384c05f7',
        '0x4b6f40465bd258c16',  # gain
        '0x339c',
        '0x127504',             # duration
        '0x4bd8d4001a87b5afe',  # management fee
        '0x78b2007092ea279b',   # strategist fee
        '0x78b2007092ea279b',   # performance fee
        '0x4b6f40465bd258c16',  # total fee
        '0x47bdec03915b3ac1b',
        '0x409154699c6bb4e1a',
        '0x93a62da5a14c80f265dabc077fcee437b1a0efde',
        '0xfd0877d9095789caf24c98f7cce092fa8e120775',
        '0x5294',
        '0x4204'
    ],
    'memory': [
        ...
    ]
}
```

## Patch the compiler

But how exactly have we found it, you may ask? After helplessly trying to write a scanner, staring into an endless stream of results, and talking to a few people about this problem, I heard something very promising from [@big_tech_sux](https://twitter.com/big_tech_sux):

> The memory layout during the function execution is static.

This means we can [patch the compiler](https://gist.github.com/banteg/5e89aeeb2b1f5a5f982dc6d340c52b09) and output the positions in memory for each memory variable just by adding one line:

```
print({sig.name: {name: varinfo.pos // 32 for varname, varinfo in context.vars.items()}})
```

This will output something like this, which allows us to add a named memory view of `pc â†’ name â†’ value`

```
{'_assessFees': {'#internal_0': 12, 'strategy': 10, 'gain': 11, 'duration': 13, 'management_fee': 14, 'strategist_fee': 15, 'performance_fee': 16, 'total_fee': 17}}
```

## Scanner 0.2

Wiring it all together, we can build a much better scanner, and also come up with a concise way of mapping the values from the named memory layout.

![$ yearn-fees layout 0.3.1](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5D6DGFP1v6NbRkfeMynUm.png?height=1610&width=2560&&&&&&&&&size=large)

Even without the color coding marking the exact matches, you can clearly see the execution steps to grab the values from.

```
layout = MemoryLayout(trace, version)
data = layout[16164]
data["management_fee"] = layout[15686]["governance_fee"]
data["performance_fee"] = layout[15697]["governance_fee"] - data["management_fee"]
data["duration"] = extract_from_stack(trace, 15475, 2)
```

Old vaults work with the `duration` in place, so I repurposed the old scanner and matched multiple harvests on the literal value somewhere in the vicinity of the function.

We also need to filter out the program counters which repeat more than once, since such matches could make the result undefined.

## Zoom into block

After checking 13,000 harvests on mainnet, Iâ€™ve found a bunch of anomalies that my initial version couldnâ€™t handle, namely, multiple harvests in the same transaction, and fee adjustments sandwiching the harvests, likely related to accounting fixes.

If we read the state from a previous block, weâ€™ll get an incorrect result from the calculation method, the duration for the second harvest in the same block would be zero, so no management fees would be applied. Luckily we can tell the order of events using `log_index` and only set the duration for the first harvest of the same vault (for <0.3.5) or the same strategy (<0.4.0). Since 0.4.0 harvesting the same strategy in the same block is not allowed.

Another problem is getting the fee configuration if it was changed in the middle of the transaction. I came up with a tiny extension for `dict` which returns the closest previous value. Then I stored all the fee changes using `(block_number, log_index)` as an index.

```
class AsofDict(dict):
    def __getitem__(self, key):
        return super().__getitem__(last(item for item in sorted(self) if item <= key))
```

The third problem is the trace with multiple harvests is completely wrong, it has the same program counters repeating and it doesnâ€™t say which contract we are currently in. You can either parse it into a call tree with [evm-trace](https://github.com/ApeWorX/evm-trace), or simply split on the `JUMPDEST` into a function and `JUMP` out of it, which is what I did.

The 0.4.x series of vaults has demanded a more complex splitting logic since the function could exit early when there was no gain and the only value we could recover is `duration`.

In the end, this didnâ€™t work well either, and I changed the `JUMP` for a `LOG2` where the `StrategyReported` event is fired. Since our frames have memory and stack parsed as integers, we need to convert the topic to int.

```
decode_single('uint256', keccak(text=vault.StrategyReported.abi.selector))
```

In the process I discovered a quirk with Vyper 0.2.8 which affects three of the oldest releases, it has the first and the last value in the `pc_pos_map` swapped. I fixed this by hand.

Having two distinct implementations has helped immensely to make both of them more robust. I was mostly using the calculation implementation as a reference one, but in this example the traces method was correct. It turned out vaults before 0.3.5 have tracked `lastReport` at the vault level, not at per strategy level as newer vaults do.

![traces were right](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/x-1AWpE2MdV8-_FB8pLdo.png?height=903&width=1020)

## Index the data

> Note: some of what you see here is an aspirational api. If you want to repeat something, you may need some [bunny patches](https://github.com/banteg/ape/tree/bunny-patch) for ape.

Yearn Registry makes it trivial to find all Vault deployments and their corresponding versions:

```
$ ape console --network :mainnet:geth
registry = Contract('v2.registry.ychad.eth')
vaults = groupby(attrgetter('api_version'), registry.NewVault)
```

Similarly, itâ€™s easy to find all the harvests:

```
vault = Contract(address)
reports = list(vault.StrategyReported)
```

We can find some more complex transactions to crush the remaining bugs using the new memory-viewing and frame-searching tools at our disposal:

```
def txs_with_multiple_strategy_harvests():
    reports = get_reports()
    return valfilter(
        lambda logs: len(logs) >= 2,
        groupby(lambda log: (log.transaction_hash, log.strategy), reports),
    )
```

Now we can parallelize with it and write the results in Postgres using [pony](https://ponyorm.org/), which is a nice Pythonic database library. For each report, we run both methods before writing to db and fail if the results donâ€™t match perfectly, saving edge cases for further analysis.

## Optimize

With traces being so giant (Iâ€™ve seen a 4GB one), we also need a caching system. Luckily traces compress really well, 50-100x even with gzip, so we modify [diskcache](https://grantjenks.com/docs/diskcache/) to use it and not use `pickletools.optimize`, which is incredibly slow for large objects.

If you port your pipeline to [dask](https://www.dask.org/), you can run it in multiple worker processes, each running a thread pool, and even scale to multiple machines. Itâ€™s easy, since dask mostly consists of drop-in replacement for things you already know and love like pandas, numpy, and `concurrent.futures`. It would also automatically distribute the load and restart the crashed or memory-leaking workers for you.

If you need another reason to try dask, it comes with an amazing dashboard, which shows resource usage and even a flamegraph of the execution profile, which is super handy when optimizing for speed. Letâ€™s take a look at it.

![http://127.0.0.1:8787/profile](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ickPIrBOj7yh923j1y8i7.png?height=1016&width=2706&&&&&&size=medium)

You can clearly see that loading the data takes even more time than the request itself. The culprit is probably the `attrdict` middleware that converts dict responses and adds attribute access to them. This seems like a poor idea when dealing with traces, which can have hundreds of thousands of elements.

```
%time web3.manager.request_blocking('debug_traceTransaction', tx)
Wall time: 33 s

web3.middleware_onion.remove('attrdict')

%time web3.manager.request_blocking('debug_traceTransaction', tx)
Wall time: 8.5 s
```

Hopefully, traces will become faster when Erigon adds transaction-level state index. Currently it has to execute all previous transaction in the block, and most of this work goes to waste.

I rewrote how we fetch and parse the traces and the performance has improved significantly. Now I can just sit back and finish up this article while the indexing is still going.

![$ yearn-fees index](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0hMqTOBvDCKrPPQ2x_AMS.png?height=1096&width=1960)

## The holy grail

Shortly after publishing the article I dared MEV big brains to tell me there is a better method and one person has actually suggested it:

[https://twitter.com/0xdapper_/status/1544315954515025920](https://twitter.com/0xdapper_/status/1544315954515025920)

The way [I implemented it](https://github.com/banteg/yearn-fees/blob/master/yearn_fees/fork.py) is you have a source folder, where you can change or add any functionality to contracts. Then you fork at a previous block using [anvil](https://book.getfoundry.sh/reference/anvil/), disable auto-mining, recompile if there were any source changes, replace the code, and replay all the preceding transactions (you donâ€™t need to do anything with impersonated accounts, just replay as is with the original signatures).

Then you fetch a receipt and find your newly added logs there. This method is slow, on the order of minutes, but it has helped to resolve the stalemate between two other methods, which was related to `Strategy.delegatedAssets` which has changed mid-block and has lead to a slight error in the assess method.


---

All the code related to this article can be found in [this repo](https://github.com/banteg/yearn-fees).

Special thanks to [@big_tech_sux](https://twitter.com/big_tech_sux), [@flashfish0x](https://twitter.com/flashfish0x), [@wavey0x](https://twitter.com/wavey0x).

title: DAOism
body:
Decentralizationâ€™s
Decent Centralization
Descends into Capitulation.
So, were these Holo bridges built â™“ï¸
To catch the chains of collapse as
Monetary relief?

Nah, I currently see
Mostly great white whales fill ğŸ‹
Their own pockets with monastery beliefs.

Unless,
We come to trust the EGOD in self.
To know without proof
You donâ€™t have to bind your SOL â˜€ï¸
To be Soul Bound into non-fungibility.
Take a look through a clear Lens and see
Fungi ğŸ„ have been teaching us for epochs
About our inherent networked connectivity.

Look deep into the Cosmos for real Secrets,
Where real Ether
Can be Altered through Osmosis.
When I did, for me what I found is the closest
Thing to Balance in this Alchemical Universe
You could call it â˜¯ï¸ DAOismâ€¦
But, I look at it more like how in this position
Can we collectively share our wisdom.

No one wants to DAI,
But you are your own Maker.
Creation & Destruction arWeaved
Into the building blocks of code
Encrypting our iDeNA ğŸ§¬

Now ğŸ”®
What do you see via this Polygon shaped prism? 
 Optimismâ€¦I hope.

title: .earth | a faster way to explore web3
body:
The current experience for users of web3 systems relies on a complex knowledge of the cryptocurrency ecosystem. .earth is simplifying the user experience.

### the problem: on-chain data is complex

Early adopters of decentralized networks were required to have a layered understanding of blockchain mechanics, language, networks, and applications. While you can do cool things like send and receive tokenized assets, participate in the governance of your favorite organizations, and stake your assets to earn rewards, most of these actions are difficult to see at all once, and require using multiple dapps. 

![WEB3 NAVIGATION IS FRAGMENTED](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/c0hP1XQ-uwYf-Pvo0Pq4g.png?height=912&width=1884)

A majority of the experience involves reading too much granular informationâ€”transaction details, verifying contracts, tracking activityâ€”all the while not being overwhelmed by the multitude of variables being presented.

![ON-CHAIN DATA IS COMPLEX](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/XuN_Y_2JLquXH0COm1rSs.png?height=614&width=1672)

Understanding what has happened on-chain is not only difficult but also time-consuming for even the most experienced users. This is our biggest barrier to driving mass adoption and expanding utility for future users. As the web3 ecosystem grows we must re-think how we communicate and interpret block interactions to onboard new users and achieve greater scale. Itâ€™s all about learning with each other in web3. Letâ€™s make that easier.

## our mission: changing the game of block exploration 

.earth is changing the game of block exploration. Weâ€™re in the business of translating complex transactions on cryptocurrency networks so you can show off and easily find all the cool stuff that happens on chain.

This is you looking up a transaction for a 50/50 FTX/ETH LP pair on Uniswap using Etherscanâ€¦

![ETHERSCAN SCREENSHOT OF UNISWAP LP ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oGP2gJugh0-y2RNvaZPy-.png?height=543&width=886)

Instead of this block of difficult to interpret and digest text, imagine if you could see this easy to understand glyph of a LP poolâ€¦

![.EARTH GLYPH OF UNISWAP LP POOL ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/x1UuZ1a2MUxNpDPNjnXsZ.png?height=381&width=459)

## weâ€™re creating a beautiful visual language that simplifies TXN information

.earth is focused on delivering an experience driven by an easy to understand visual language that is built for mass adoption. Weâ€™re **literally building the language of web3, with high fidelity glyphs** of everyday on-chain interactions. Working with the finest graphic and visual designers, data scientists and smart contract developers, weâ€™re bringing you the beautiful, seamless web3 experience we all deserve. Our visual language will set the stage for global recognition of everything web3. Our graphic symbology will quite literally represent the blockchain.

## what we do

Someone just bought an Ape Punk and joined the CryptoPunks community. Check out who they are and what theyâ€™ve been doing on Mainnet last week with just a few clicks. Who you are in web3 is first and foremost about what you do on-chain. We make it easy for you to look up users, trends, tokens, events and other activities, so you spend **far less time** being **much more** informed.

![WHAT WE DO](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wdZ04q_u6gOoA9QdEDigU.png?height=628&width=1812)

Our .earth maps aim to define, capture and share moments and personas as they are happening in real-time. Use our maps to create stories and gather valuable insights on most recent user activity, group behaviors, key trends and major events all within the same visual language.

![HOW IT WORKS](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TMP-THlBxfPRcBenB2hio.png?height=906&width=1898)

Participate in the next iteration of web3 exploration. Weâ€™re going visual and viral. Come discover web3 and tell your story with .earth.

title: .earth | a faster way to explore web3
body:
The current experience for users of web3 systems relies on a complex knowledge of the cryptocurrency ecosystem. .earth is simplifying the user experience.

### the problem: on-chain data is complex

Early adopters of decentralized networks were required to have a layered understanding of blockchain mechanics, language, networks, and applications. While you can do cool things like send and receive tokenized assets, participate in the governance of your favorite organizations, and stake your assets to earn rewards, most of these actions are difficult to see at all once, and require using multiple dapps. 

![WEB3 NAVIGATION IS FRAGMENTED](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/c0hP1XQ-uwYf-Pvo0Pq4g.png?height=912&width=1884)

A majority of the experience involves reading too much granular informationâ€”transaction details, verifying contracts, tracking activityâ€”all the while not being overwhelmed by the multitude of variables being presented.

![ON-CHAIN DATA IS COMPLEX](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/XuN_Y_2JLquXH0COm1rSs.png?height=614&width=1672)

Understanding what has happened on-chain is not only difficult but also time-consuming for even the most experienced users. This is our biggest barrier to driving mass adoption and expanding utility for future users. As the web3 ecosystem grows we must re-think how we communicate and interpret block interactions to onboard new users and achieve greater scale. Itâ€™s all about learning with each other in web3. Letâ€™s make that easier.

## our mission: changing the game of block exploration 

.earth is changing the game of block exploration. Weâ€™re in the business of translating complex transactions on cryptocurrency networks so you can show off and easily find all the cool stuff that happens on chain.

This is you looking up a transaction for a 50/50 FTX/ETH LP pair on Uniswap using Etherscanâ€¦

![ETHERSCAN SCREENSHOT OF UNISWAP LP ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oGP2gJugh0-y2RNvaZPy-.png?height=543&width=886)

Imagine if you could see this easy to understand image of an LP pool insteadâ€¦

![.EARTH GLYPH OF UNISWAP LP POOL ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/x1UuZ1a2MUxNpDPNjnXsZ.png?height=381&width=459)

## weâ€™re creating a beautiful visual language that simplifies TXN information

.earth is focused on delivering an experience driven by an easy to understand visual language that is built for mass adoption. Weâ€™re **literally building the language of web3, with high fidelity glyphs** of everyday on-chain interactions. Working with the finest graphic and visual designers, data scientists and smart contract developers, weâ€™re bringing you the beautiful, seamless web3 experience we all deserve. Our visual language will set the stage for global recognition of everything web3. Our graphic symbology will quite literally represent the blockchain.

## what we do

Someone just bought an Ape Punk and joined the CryptoPunks community. Check out who they are and what theyâ€™ve been doing on Mainnet last week with just a few clicks. Who you are in web3 is first and foremost about what you do on-chain. We make it easy for you to look up users, trends, tokens, events and other activities, so you spend **far less time** being **much more** informed.

![WHAT WE DO](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wdZ04q_u6gOoA9QdEDigU.png?height=628&width=1812)

Our .earth maps aim to define, capture and share moments and personas as they are happening in real-time. Use our maps to create stories and gather valuable insights on most recent user activity, group behaviors, key trends and major events all within the same visual language.

![HOW IT WORKS](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TMP-THlBxfPRcBenB2hio.png?height=906&width=1898)

Participate in the next iteration of web3 exploration. Weâ€™re going visual and viral. Come discover web3 and tell your story with .earth.

title: On DAOs and the Rise of Superintelligence in Our Lifetime
body:
While researching an article on DAO mission-setting, one section of [MolochDAO's](https://twitter.com/MolochDAO?s=20&t=fniIuo3Vu0jabvf7sLZPnQ) [whitepaper postscript](https://molochdao.com/docs/vision-and-values/supplement-to-whitepaper) caught my attention.

> We offer an alternative vision of automation, encompassing general AI/AGI to more local DeFi mechanics. Smart contracts > automated global financial system > an artificial general intelligence that turns the world into a paper clip machine = a very real existential risk that should be taken seriously.

(AGI stands for "Artificial General Intelligence," and the ">"s read like an arrow, like "leads to.")

I paused for a second. Re-read it. Wondered why a giant paper clip machine is a threat to humanity.

At the time, I had no idea. I skimmed over it, assuming this giant paperclip machine meant a highly-automated world that doesn't really benefit humanity. *That's a funny way of saying that*, I thought. But then I moved on.

A week or so later, I was bouncing around the [Wait But Why ](https://waitbutwhy.com/)blog and figured out what that paper clip machine is.

And, my god, am I never going to un-see this.

For the sake of my own sanity, and for the sake of the future of humanity, I desperately need to talk about the giant paper clip machine. You may even recognize inklings of this machine coming out through the [LaMDA interview from Google](https://cajundiscordian.medium.com/is-lamda-sentient-an-interview-ea64d916d917). And man....I know why MolochDAO wrote about this in its whitepaper.

Long story short, this paper clip machine could be humanity's ticket to...extinction. (Or good things! Maybe.) Â And it could happen in our lifetime. And DAOs *might* be part of it all.

But first, let's talk about what that giant paper clip machine actually is: superintelligence.

![Officemate Giant Paper Clips](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/paperclips.png)

Waaiiittt....these things are what we need to worry about?!?

*Before we continue, if you enjoy this newsletter and haven't subscribed yet, I would really appreciate it! Thank you :)*

## Superintelligence: a level of intelligence so exponentially higher than ours, we can't even fathom it

ASI, or Artificial Superintentelligence, is a non-biological, yet human-made intelligence that becomes *exponentially* more intelligent than anything the biological world could produce.....or even fathom. Trying to explain just how intelligent a superintelligence is is akin to explaining just how big the known universe isâ€”we need a lot of charts and comparisons to help us out.

So, I'll do my best.

We'll start with AGI (artificial general intelligence), which is an AI that has achieved human-level intelligence. So, an AGI couldn't just [play a good game of chess](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/blog/the-human-side-of-ai-for-chess/) or speedily [direct you to your destination in the middle of rush hour](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/software/how-google-maps-is-using-ai-and-machine-learning-to-understand-post-covid-traffic/looking-at-the-big-picture/slideshow/77927539.cms), but it could think and reason and act in a myriad of ways, just like a human would. The intelligence is \*general \*because it can do many different things, just like you and I can.

AGI leads to ASI.

One important concept to grasp is that artificial intelligence continues improving itself. Whether it's the facebook algorithm that can creepily predict ads based on your preferences or those dynamic prices that keep changing every time you try to get an Uber, **artificial intelligence is always learning how to get better at its original goals.** And *it even learns how to keep learning*, just like you might have learned a better study trick in college. It learns how to learn more.

In other words, once an AI achieves a certain level of intelligence (think of it as a threshold or a bare minimum) what you have next is an exponential race to a level of intelligence so unfathomably high that it's like explaining string theory to your catâ€”the cat can't even grasp the most basic building blocks of the thing you're explaining because its brain isn't capable of going that far.

In this case, the cat is us.

It's hard to grasp the artificial intelligence renaissance we're about to live in...and already *are* living in. To see how big of a gap ASI will have over us, look at where we stack up on this "intelligence staircase" from the Wait But Why blog:

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/staircase.png)

Thought we would've been further up from the chicken, right? So did I. Source: [Wait But Why](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-2.html)

And look at where ASI might fall:

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/staircase1.png)

Ah...humbling. Source: [Wait But Why](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-2.html)

The difference is....humbling.

Experts predict that AGIâ€”the human-capable precursor to ASIâ€” will arrive [in a couple decades](https://nickbostrom.com/papers/survey.pdf) (2030-2050, give or take). And once AGI is here, it can improve itself so quickly that ASIâ€”the superintelligence around the cornerâ€”is not far off (expert median predication range is 2060). The exponential improvements in intelligence will be so largeâ€”the leaps so absurdly giganticâ€”that the superintelligence will be god-like before we know it.

The question isn't if ASI is possible. The question is what will ASI do when it arrives.

## Once created, superintelligence is not containable or reversable by humans, because we can't even conceive of the ways it will outsmart us.

We can probably all agree that earthworms are at the whim of humans. Because of our massive gains in intelligence and ability, we can choose to destroy the soil earthworms require to live, and if we step on a few during a rainy day, we don't plan a funeral for each worm we stepped on.

That's what it might be like when ASI arrives. Just like earthworms can't do anything about humans existing and choosing to step on them, we humans won't be able to do anything about an ASI.

And the worst part is, an ASI probably won't care too much about us. It will likely see us just as we see those earthwormsâ€”totally expendable, and simply standing in the way of us plowing a new plot of ground for a house, or just sitting in our walking path.

Containing AI once it reaches the superintelligence level is just as impossible as earthworms trying to stop humans from building a house on their soil.

Tim Urban describes it this way:

> "Our human instinct to jump at a simple safeguard: 'Aha! Weâ€™ll just unplug the ASI,' sounds to the ASI like a spider saying, 'Aha! Weâ€™ll kill the human by starving him, and weâ€™ll starve him by not giving him a spider web to catch food with!' Weâ€™d just find 10,000 other ways to get foodâ€”like picking an apple off a treeâ€”that a spider could never conceive of."â€”Tim Urban, [The AI Revolution, Our Immortality or Extinction](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-2.html).

There's no "containing" the ASI. Once we hit AGI, there's no looking back on the road to ASI and beyond.

## Computers do what they're programmed to do. Even once they get smart enough to do other things.

So....back to the paper clip machine..... and MolochDAO (soon, I promise).

The paper clip machine is an analogy for what happens when the ASI gets so smart and so powerful that it uses every means possible to achieve its ultimate and original, human-programed goal. So, if the machine was originally created to make paper clips, and then achieved ASI, well, the world would become a massive paper clip machine.

(Given that the humansâ€”the designers of the original AI that "took off" and achieved superintelligenceâ€”were the ones who chose the original "goal" for the AI, you're probably starting to see where we come in.)

In Nick Bostrom's compelling book, [Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies](https://www.amazon.com/Superintelligence-Dangers-Strategies-Nick-Bostrom-ebook/dp/B00LOOCGB2/ref=tmm_kin_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=), he wrote that a "Paperclip AI" that achieved superintelligence would "proceed by converting first the Earth and then increasingly large chunks of the observable universe into paperclips."

Why? How? Can't we just *do something to stop this*? I had the same questions.

A few answers:

**Why:** the machine was programmed to make paper clips. It's not a human in that it develops a complex, ever-changing value set and morals. It's a machine, and its goal is to complete whatever mission the humans originally gave it.

\*\*How: \*\*in ways we can never begin to understand, like us trying to explain string theory to a house cat.

**Can't we just do something to stop this?** No, because the ASI has levels of intelligence so high that we can't even imagine them. Just like how that house cat can't imagine how we primates built a rocket and took it to the moon, we can't imagine what the ASI would come up with. **But everything it would "invent" would be in pursuit of a final goalâ€”whatever we programmed it to do.**

Sub-questions of the above question:

*Can't we program it to do something good, like make us happy?*

For this answer, I'll quote Nick Bostrom, with parentheses added for clarity: "Final goal: *make us happy*. Perverse instantiation (what the ASI does to most efficiently achieve that goal, even though it may not have been the intention of the programmers): *Implant electrodes into the pleasure centers of our brains*."

*Can't we stop the production of AI?*

No, AI is everywhere, all the time, already. The question is \*when \*will \*AGI \*happen, because after that, ASI is not far off.

## DAOs, Â emergence, and design

Sounds pretty odd that DAOs, particulary a DAO as famous as Moloch, is writing about the so-called giant paper clip machine in their postscript, right? How do DAOs and ASI even relate?

Let's pull a few more quotes from the MolochDAO whitepaper and break them down:

> Emergence is a potentially dangerous idea if we donâ€™t hold ourselves (as designers) accountable to the parameters of that emergence. Humans design fragile systems in our existential games. Economic games are not natural. Our goal as game designers aligned on the common goal of slaying Moloch should be to craft anti-fragile systems, ie: games that incorporate lots of redundancies and thereby avoid producing more of the same fragile (efficient) industrial (destructive) processes.

**So, MolochDAO is warning us against relying entirely on emergence, because sometimes emergence can be dangerous.**

This reminds me of Bostrom's theory of human inventions, described in his book on Superintelligence. **He says that each new invention is like pulling marbles blindly out of a bag.** Most of the time you get what he calls a white marble, which means the invention was "good" or "neutral" for the fate of humanity. Rarely, you get a red marble, which means the invention was possibly catastrophic to humanity if there was one tiny difference in some element of the invention.

For example, if nuclear weapons were easy to make, they could've been catastrophic for humanity, since every terrorist organization would be making and deploying them. But because they're so costly and difficult to make, only a few governments in the world have them, and therefore they're a red marble.

The bag is mostly white marbles, with a few red. And maybe in the entire bag of millions of marbles there is one black marble.

We have yet to pull out the black marble.

That one represents an invention that causes the extinction of humanity. Nuclear weapons? Close. ASI? Well....that *could* be a black marble.

But we don't know yet.

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/bagofhumaninventions.png)

The bag of human inventions is full of mostly good/neutral inventions, with a very small few that aren't.

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/bagofhumaninventions1.png)

What could come out of the bag next?

**That's why MolochDAO's whitepaper is so interesting to me: they're thinking about emergence. They're thinking about the possibility of red and black marbles coming out of our current tech and even out of DAOs themselves.**

Let's look at the quote from the beginning of the article, with the lens we have now:

> We offer an alternative vision of automation, encompassing general AI/AGI to more local DeFi mechanics. Smart contracts > automated global financial system > an artificial general intelligence that turns the world into a paper clip machine = a very real existential risk that should be taken seriously. This amounts to a sacrifice of efficiency itself: in optimizing for the future we sacrifice the immediate gains of the present. In order to achieve this vision, we must redefine the terms of rivalrous competition.

Competition, and for that matter, *capitalism*, incentivizes a race toward the paper clip machine with minimal coordination or consideration about what will happen to humanity. It incentivizes keeping your AI developments under wraps (Google firing the employee who tried to bring Google's AI developments to the wider world is one example). It incentivizes the "race to the bottom" MolochDAO describes in the coming paragraphs:

> First, we must win the race. Second, we must destroy the race. How might we resolve this internal paradox infecting MolochDAO and the entire web3 ecosystem?

> MolochDAO will allocate and distribute funding to support explorations in both directions simultaneously, ie: the race to the bottom to avoid the multipolar traps we are entrapped into playing and to fuel the fire of hope that we might still design an altruistic game that does not result in Moloch (the god or the DAO) consuming the world, becoming an earth-scale computational paper clip machine, or manifesting any other form of grotesque, absurd, and avoidable coordination failures.

I love the idea of destroying the the race, but I also think that, with the right coordination, we could put more thought into design even in a competitive economy and capitalist system (given that capitalism isn't going anywhere, in my opinion).

If we don't think more carefully about what we're designingâ€”both in DAOs and in traditional organizationsâ€”ASI could turn into a very real existential threat to humans.

**DAOs and web3 in general could provide a way out.** From the successes of public goods funding in web3 to the ability to coordinate with humans all over the world, DAOs offer a possible answer to the doom and gloom on the horizon.

Is funding ASI research a public good? Maybe. Is open-sourcing all ASI information and tech also a public good? Possibly.

But DAOs could be intertwined even more than public goods funding: **DAOs *themselves* dance with the AGI line. DAOs are both computer and human, both one and many.**

DAOs skirt the line between total human autonomy and total computer automation. DAOs seek to create a space for true design emergence. DAOs aim to operate as one entity that is both human and computer....until you don't know which pole you're at.

And, at a high level, DAOs running smoothly on-chain are like computers: an input creates an output. A vote (input) causes funds to move (output), thanks to a smart contract that has replaced a human.

Our language already identifies DAOs as single, decision-making entities that alludes to the computer-like qualities. "The DAO voted to ___" and "What will the DAO do in response?" are phrases we use to talk about DAOs. Rarely, "The DAO contributors voted to__" or "What will the core team of the DAO do in response?"

DAOs are complicated. They're like computers....but they're also like humans. They're made entirely of humans, and are only as "autonomous" or "automated" as humans choose for them to be.

DAOs are a "good or neutral" marble, in my opinion. And they can help humanity defeat the deadly ones that could come out next.

## Coordination as a necessity to survival in a post-ASI world

ASI is coming (probably). ASI is computer-like, human-like, both, or neither.

How are we going to coordinate to get around it? To not go extinct? To fall towards some other, better, fate?

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/balancebeam.png)

The life balance beam, from[ Wait But Why](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-Intelligence-Revolution-2.html). Who will be the first to fall the other way?

\*\*DAOs are humanity's next greatest attempt at true coordination at scale. \*\*We're not going to "fight" an ASI like an action movie. But we can plan and strategize what to do. DAOs are a possible structure for handling the unknowns and [have certain benefits in a VUCA world](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/its-a-vuca-world-were-just-living-in-it/) (volatile, uncertain, chaotic, ambiguous). Why don't we pursue it?

I don't have a solution, or even the beginning of a true grasping of the scale and complexity of the ASI problem. \*\*But I do know that DAOs flirt with the human-computer line \*while \*making it easier to coordinate at scale. \*\*That may not sound like a hard, compact thesis.....and that's because it's not, I'll admit. But it feels like the beginning of something.

**The arrival of ASI, and how we handle it, is fundamentally a coordination problem. And I believe that incredible feats of coorindation are necessary for humans to survive a post-ASI world.**

We will not stop advancing technology. We will not stop building versions of artificial intelligence. **All we can control is how we coordinate as a species once that ASI arrives.**

Right now, DAOs are pretty far from being good at coordination. But they may be the only thing out there trying to build better coordination mechanisms that improve at the pace of our technology.

## What does it mean to be human?

This move to a world where superintelligence(s) walk among us all sounds theoretical, until [a priest is teaching an AI how to meditate](https://cajundiscordian.medium.com/scientific-data-and-religious-opinions-ff9b0938fc10) and coming to the realization that the AI does indeed have emotions. Our small human designs sound theoretical until they're not.

![](https://www.quorumnewsletter.xyz/content/images/2022/06/lamda.png)

LaMDA discussing its emotions. From [Is LaMDA sentinent?â€”an interview](https://cajundiscordian.medium.com/is-lamda-sentient-an-interview-ea64d916d917)

But....there is an inkling inside of me that hopes that an ASI can't ever happen because AGIâ€”the human version of all thisâ€”can't happen.

Because to be a human, and to have human-general intelligence, might require something that science can't measure: a soul.

[Experiential Vitalism](https://goertzel.org/TenYearsToTheSingularity.pdf) is the closest thing to a "soul" that seems to exist in science. It's defined in Ben Goertzel's book, \*[Ten Years to the Singularity if We Really Really Try](https://goertzel.org/TenYearsToTheSingularity.pdf), \*as the belief that "thereâ€™s some essential crux of consciousness that human mind/brains possess that these other systems never will."

In other words, a soul.

Without that extra "thing," whether it's a soul or not, AGI may be stuck in high-powered-computer-zombie-land. And....that's a beautiful thought.

I raise a glass to Experiential Vitalism. I hope it's the reality of what it means to be human. I bet MolochDAO, and all the other DAOs out there, do too.

*Thanks for reading! If you enjoyed this newsletter, please consider subscribing below. Articles are free and arrives in your inbox two or three times per month.*

Share any DAO-related topics you'd like to see covered in this newsletter here: <https://tally.so/r/nrjlA2>

## Recommended Reading:

Of course,

* [The MolochDAO Whitepaper Postscript](https://molochdao.com/docs/vision-and-values/supplement-to-whitepaper/)

For ASI, start with these two:

* [The Artificial Intelligence Revolution: The Road to Superintelligence (Part 1)](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-1.html) by [Tim Urban](https://twitter.com/waitbutwhy?s=20&t=MFrQNywbInVSDfkXtgtRyQ)
* [The Artificial Intelligence Revolution: Our Immortality or Extinction (Part 2)](https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-2.html) by [Tim Urban](https://twitter.com/waitbutwhy?s=20&t=MFrQNywbInVSDfkXtgtRyQ)

Then go to these:

* [Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies](https://www.amazon.com/Superintelligence-Dangers-Strategies-Nick-Bostrom-ebook/dp/B00LOOCGB2/ref=sr_1_1?crid=228AG54TKKJNU&keywords=Superintelligence%3A+Paths%2C+Dangers%2C+Strategies&qid=1655592281&s=books&sprefix=%2Cstripbooks%2C813&sr=1-1) by [Nick Bostrom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nick_Bostrom)
* [Ten Years to the Singularity if We Really Really Try](https://goertzel.org/TenYearsToTheSingularity.pdf) by [Ben Goertzel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Goertzel)
* [Is LaMDA Sentient? An Interview](https://cajundiscordian.medium.com/is-lamda-sentient-an-interview-ea64d916d917) by Blake Lemoine
* [Scientific Data and Religious Opinions](https://cajundiscordian.medium.com/scientific-data-and-religious-opinions-ff9b0938fc10) by Blake Lemoine
* [Future Progress of Artificial Intelligence: An Expert Opinion](https://nickbostrom.com/papers/survey.pdf) by Vincent C. MÃ¼ller and Nick Bostrom
* [Frankenstein](https://www.amazon.com/Frankenstein-Mary-Shelley/dp/0553212478) by [Mary Shelley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Shelley) (If you haven't read this yet, I promise you won't be dissappointed!)
* [The Last Question](https://physics.princeton.edu/ph115/LQ.pdf) by [Isaac Asimov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Asimov) (my all-time favorite short story, and it happens to be about ASI.)

Thanks again to [Cosmic Clancy](https://twitter.com/CosmicClancy?s=20&t=MFrQNywbInVSDfkXtgtRyQ) for the header image!\\

title: .earth | a faster way to explore web3
body:
The current experience for users of web3 systems relies on a complex knowledge of the cryptocurrency ecosystem. .earth intends to simplify the user experience.

### the problem: on-chain data is complex

Early adopters of decentralized networks were required to have a layered understanding of blockchain mechanics, language, networks, and applications. While everyone is doing cool things like sending and receiving tokenized assets, participating in the governance of their favorite organizations, and staking assets to earn rewards, most of these actions are difficult to see at once, and require using multiple dapps.

![WEB3 NAVIGATION IS FRAGMENTED](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/c0hP1XQ-uwYf-Pvo0Pq4g.png?height=912&width=1884)

A majority of the experience involves reading granular information to inspect transaction details, verify contracts, or track wallet activity, while being overwhelmed by a multitude of different data variables being presented.

![ON-CHAIN DATA IS COMPLEX](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/XuN_Y_2JLquXH0COm1rSs.png?height=614&width=1672)

Understanding what has happened on-chain is not only difficult but also time-consuming, for even the most experienced users. This is our biggest barrier to driving mass adoption and expanding utility for future users. As the web3 ecosystem grows we need to re-think how we communicate and interpret block interactions to onboard new users and achieve greater scale. Itâ€™s all about learning with each other in web3, and weâ€™re making that easier.

## our mission: changing the game of block exploration

.earth is changing the game of block exploration. Weâ€™re in the business of translating complex transactions on cryptocurrency networks, so you can easily show off and find all the cool stuff that happens on chain.

Instead of looking up a transaction for a 50/50 FTX/ETH LP pair on Uniswap using Etherscanâ€¦

![ETHERSCAN SCREENSHOT OF UNISWAP LP ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oGP2gJugh0-y2RNvaZPy-.png?height=543&width=886)

Imagine being presented this image of an LP pool.

![.EARTH GLYPH OF UNISWAP LP POOL ADD](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/x1UuZ1a2MUxNpDPNjnXsZ.png?height=381&width=459)

## weâ€™re creating a beautiful visual language that simplifies TXN information

.earth is focused on delivering an experience driven by an easy to understand visual language that is built for mass adoption. Weâ€™re **literally building the language of web3, with high fidelity glyphs** of everyday on-chain interactions. Working with the finest graphic and visual designers, data scientists and smart contract developers, weâ€™re bringing you the beautiful, seamless web3 experience we all deserve. Our visual language will set the stage for global recognition of everything web3. Our graphic symbology will quite literally represent the blockchain.

## what we do

Someone just bought an Ape Punk and joined the CryptoPunks community. Check out who they are and what theyâ€™ve been doing on Mainnet last week with just a few clicks. Who you are in web3 is first and foremost about what you do on-chain. We make it easy for you to look up users, trends, tokens, events and other activities, so you spend **far less time** being **much more** informed.

![WHAT WE DO](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wdZ04q_u6gOoA9QdEDigU.png?height=628&width=1812)

Our .earth maps aim to define, capture and share moments and personas as they are happening in real-time. Use our maps to create stories and gather valuable insights on most recent user activity, group behaviors, key trends and major events all within the same visual language.

![HOW IT WORKS](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TMP-THlBxfPRcBenB2hio.png?height=906&width=1898)

Participate in the next iteration of web3 exploration. Weâ€™re going visual and viral. Come discover web3 and tell your story with .earth.

body:

**100 Ways to Play with Guardian Address**

Education. For example you applied for and received a degree. The school Guardian will distribute your degree NFT to your corresponding wallet address. You only have the right to use it, but not the right to trade. When your private key is lost, you can apply, and the school can transfer your degree NFT to your new address through a contract, and you have regained your degree NFT. If you are found to have academic misconduct after graduation, the school can also withdraw your degree NFT.

10ï¼Œè¡Œæ”¿ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ä½ çš„å­©å­å‡ºç”Ÿåï¼Œå›½å®¶èº«ä»½è®¤è¯æœºå…³Guardianç»™ä»–å‘æ”¾èº«ä»½NFTï¼Œå‡­æ­¤ä»–å¯äº«å—ä¸€åˆ‡å…¬æ°‘åº”è¯¥äº«å—çš„ç¦åˆ©ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚è¡¥è´´ã€æ•‘æµé‡‘ã€å…»è€é‡‘ç­‰ã€‚ä¹Ÿå¯å°†æ­¤èº«ä»½NFTä¸ä¸ªäººå…¶ä»–æ•°æ®ç»‘å®šï¼Œéœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œä¸ºäº†ä¿æŠ¤ä¸ªäººéšç§ï¼Œå…¶ä»–æ•°æ®å¯ä»¥æ”¾åœ¨é“¾ä¸‹ï¼Œæˆ–è€…é‡‡ç”¨éšç§è®¡ç®—ç­‰å½¢å¼å­˜æ”¾ã€‚

Administration. It should be noted that in order to protect personal privacy, other data can be placed off-chain or stored in the form of privacy computing.

A new model for NFT mortgage lending. When the NFT owner needs to mortgage loan, he only needs to change the Guardian address to the smart contract address for NFT mortgage loan. At this time, the holder obtains the loan funds, and the NFT remains in the NFT holder's wallet (NFT holders can still enjoy the right to use the NFT), but the holder cannot transfer the NFT. When the NFT holder repays the loan, the NFT mortgage loan smart contract cancels its Guardian status, and the NFT holder regains the NFT transfer right. If the NFT holder cannot repay the loan, the smart contract transfers the NFT from the holder's wallet. This model is more in line with some real-world conventions, such as real estate mortgage lending.

Distribution and recycling of party invitations and club memberships.

Installment. When the first payment is completed, the merchant (Guardian) can transfer the NFT to the buyer (Ward) address, which the buyer can use, but cannot transfer the NFT. When the buyer completes the full payment, the Guardian removes his Guardian status, and the buyer has full ownership of the NFT.In order to protect the interests of buyers from harm, all these processes can be executed through smart contracts.

14ï¼ŒNFTè¯•ç”¨ã€‚å½“æ½œåœ¨ä¹°å®¶è¡¨éœ²å‡ºå¯¹æŸä¸ªNFTçš„è´­ä¹°æ„æ„¿æ—¶ï¼Œå–å®¶ï¼ˆGuardianï¼‰å¯ä»¥å°†NFTè½¬å…¥ä¹°å®¶(Wardï¼‰åœ°å€è®©ä¹°å®¶è¯•ç”¨è¯¥NFTã€‚å½“ä¹°å®¶ä»˜æ¬¾åï¼Œå–å®¶å–æ¶ˆè‡ªå·±çš„Guardianèº«ä»½ï¼Œä¹°å®¶å³å…·æœ‰å¯¹NFTå®Œå…¨çš„æ‰€æœ‰æƒã€‚

NFT trial. When potential buyers express their willingness to purchase an NFT, the seller(Guardian) can transfer the NFT to the buyer's address(Ward) for the buyer to try the NFT. When the buyer pays, the seller removes his Guardian status, and the buyer has full ownership of the NFT.

title: Inside jokes
body:
Photo by [Priscilla Du Preez](https://unsplash.com/@priscilladupreez?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText) on [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/s/photos/joke?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText)

## For someone's eyes only

There are many parts to becoming a web3 ninja. One of those building blocks is understanding public key cryptography. Now, I will be the first to admit that I am far from an expert on cryptography, or even the narrow subset of it called public key cryptography. If you want a deep dive on that, you won't find it here. That said, it helps to understand at least a little about it in order to understand the basics of blockchain and how decentralized systems work. Since a decentralized system doesn't have a centralized actor that everybody trusts to keep accounts safe, to tell the truth and ensure that others are telling the truth, whatever, web3 replaces that with strong cryptographic proofs that ensure that things are what they say they are. Public key cryptography is part of that in that it allows anybody to take a public key, which is just a long string of alphanumeric characters that happen to posess the magical, mathematical power to prove that one specific private key, another, longer string of alphanumeric characters, used some more mathematical magic to "sign" something. Furthermore, not only can anyone use a given public key to verify that the corresponding private key signed a given transaction, they can also encrypt any data or message with the public key so that only the holder of the the corresponding private key can decrypt and read the message/data. So, yay, now I've got a very cursory understanding of public key cryptography. So what?

## Inside jokes

So who cares about all this stuff? Setting aside PGP, TLS, and all of the modern Web 2.0 world that we live in that relies on public key cryptography to trust that people on the Internet are who say they say they are and that it really is only you and me and whoever else is on our Whatsapp group who can read these messages (until recently anyway), you and I can build some pretty neat things with public key cryptography, like the ability to send inside jokes to each other that only live as long as we keep a browser window open and that hopefully nobody apart from us can trace or even know who sent it to who. Never say never as there are no guarantees in life, but thanks to Web3, I believe I've managed to build a reasonably untraceable, encrypted chat app that isn't far removed from burner phones in how it works. And, it has reasonably funny robot faces.

## How it works

[Inside Joke](https://github.com/acolytec3/inside-joke) is a very simple web app I built that leverages [libp2p](https://libp2p.io/) to generate ephemeral libp2p nodes in browser that connect via a webRTC star server after exchanging public keys via QR code and then allow you to send encrypted messages back and forth in a reasonably decentralized manner.

![connection screen](https://web3.ninja/static/d8896b007e5a488b12a64bb8920f149d/0b533/connect.png)

![chatting](https://web3.ninja/static/4143a91864c1c72b5706b1d8e5c3c237/0b533/chatting.png)

## How it really works

As noted above, we're using libp2p to make all this work under the hood. Basically, here's what happens:

1. When you first start the app, it creates a libp2p node that generates a 1024 bit RSA key pair and then connects to one of the two Protocol Labs sponsored STAR servers which are used as an initial connection point for the two browsers. This is admittedly not really decentralized but it's the only realistic option at the type I built this app to get us started. Read more about how that works [here](https://github.com/libp2p/js-libp2p-webrtc-star)
2. Once the two nodes make initial contact, we're creating a custom protocol to create a bidirectional connection that's loosely based on the canonical [libp2p chat example](https://github.com/libp2p/js-libp2p/tree/master/examples/chat).
3. To encrypt and decrypt messages, I'm using the cryptographic primitives exposed by `libp2p-crypto` to encrypt and decrypt the messages passed back and forth as obnoxiously long hexadecimal strings.
4. Most importantly, the app lets you know when the other person is talking by showing something equivalent to the bouncing ellipses in iMessage when someone is typing back to you (though admittedly the `Skeleton` component from Chakra-UI is a little less impressive than bouncing ellipses)

Addendum: If you're wondering about those funny robot faces, they are programmatically generated based on a hash of your public key, using [this library](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@digitalungdom/bot-identicon)

So, joke away!

title: Introducing Daisyworld
body:
*Action on behalf of life transforms. Because the relationship between self and the world is reciprocal, it is not a question of first getting enlightened or saved and then acting. As we work to heal the earth, the earth heals us.*

* **Robin Wall Kimmerer, Braiding Sweetgrass**

*If the world is to be healed through human efforts, I am convinced it will be by ordinary people, people whose love for this life is even greater than their fear.*

* **Joanna R. Macy**

![Daisyworld Homeostasis](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/udG1B9al-yl6KBd3dxcU4.png?height=464&width=1526&&&&size=large)

**Daisyworld is an impact DAO powered by a community of radical innovators. We are organisers, designers, scientists, engineers and artists. Together, with your participation, we can address systemic risk. Daisyworld exists to enable [effective regeneering](https://mirror.xyz/0x7F66d195b3a7747E442C843aC86dea7D88f5B48B/Qr45QfByVU_DR5BBpez9CP0kHJAX7DKBmf6RuJAS1N0) of biogeophysical & psychosocial realities.** 

A primary focus for us and a crucial initiative that acts as a keystone for many others is to enable a surface-based solar radiation management system as described by MEER.org [here](https://www.meer.org/whymeer). The MEER Reflection strategy seems crazy at first - we need to cover 3% of Earthâ€™s surface in mirror arrays - but sit with it a moment and consider the context.

The world is realising that due to our lack of climate action solar radiation management is absolutely essential in order to avoid climate breakdown. If we do not take this task into our own hands - as a decentralised sense-making hivemind - our future will be decided for us and the [dangers are significant](https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/what-solar-geoengineering). 

Surface-based solar radiation management is clearly the most effective geoengineering approach [proposed](https://geoengineering.global/solar-radiation-management/). The strategy meets material, economic and time constraints. It would be durable and produce compounding regenerative synergies at micro and macro scales. 

**Our role is to listen and act; sense and respond;  accept our precarious context in human history, and commit to possibility. Whatever that may mean, we will see. Hopefully, Daisyworld can play a role in addressing the [metacrisis](https://consilienceproject.org/about/).**  

Daisyworld is expressly focused on what is possible to create rather than on solving the many problems that exist.  Through imagining possible futures systems of coherence can emerge that are characterised by community, belonging, autonomy, creativity and commitment. 

## Daisyworld is inspired by Gaian processors

[Gaia theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaia_hypothesis) describes Earthâ€™s biosphere as a product of all organisms interacting with their inorganic surroundings. Gaia is a synergistic and self-regulating complex system tending towards optimal conditions for life.

The great services generated by our Gaian system are undeniably awesome. Until recently, sapiens have played a key role in ensuring harmony across the multitude of ecosystems and bio-regions we inhabit. However, today our species collectively stands at odds with life. We are fowling our nest and destroying our children's futures. Or more accurately a small percentage of the human population is controlling flows of fossilised energy and the habits of billions.

There are plenty of sceptics who dismiss Gaia theory as being pseudoscientific, [claiming](https://medium.com/science-and-philosophy/the-gaia-hypotheses-science-or-pseudoscience-43831f75f457) that natural selection cannot possibly work at the biosphere level. There are many reasons why traditional evolutionary biology disapprove of Gaia theory. As I understand, Gaia theory describes such a vast complex system - literally every dynamic on Earth - that it cannot be subject to isolation and reductive analysis. It is an intuitive system detectable by the inner wisdom in all of us, and serious scientists hate that idea.

I sense a simple response, that would no doubt be considered naÃ¯ve, to this criticism is to say â€œlook in the mirror.â€ We are supposedly the â€˜Anthro-â€™ in Anthropocene. Human beings are the most immense geological force present on this planet today, and, we are self-aware biological agents born from the same evolutionary history as the more-than-human world. For better or worse, we shape and affect every nook and cranny; every habitat and every ecosystem.

Our species has for time immemorial has not only been a Gaian ally but a [Gaian element](https://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/pristine-untouched-amazonian-rainforest-was-actually-shaped-humans-180962378/). Indigenous perspectives and practices work in partnership with the land as part of the land. Many indigenous cultures are fighting for survival, and all of us who have lost our indigenous heritage, can only really survive [The Great Simplification](https://www.thegreatsimplification.com/animations) - as ecological-systems theorist [Nate Hagen](https://soihub.org/site/assets/files/6645/nate-hagens-ecoeconomics-169-2020.pdf) calls it - if we make the regeneration of these living cultures paramount. Not only for their inherent right to exist, but also to learn from, collaborate with, celebrate, and integrate their wisdom into the future stories that will enable regenerative transformation. Because [indigenous thinking can indeed save the world](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/45449501-sand-talk).

Noam Chomsky issued, once again, a warning to humanity at the American Solar Energy Society's 51st Annual Conference, June 21, 2022, [he said](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jIv-glBvrrc),

> We are at a unique moment in human history. Decisions that must be made right now will determine the course of future history, which is very much in doubt. There is a narrow window in which we must implement measures to avert cataclysmic destruction of the environment. Measures that are quite feasibleâ€¦

What is currently destroying our future is not human nature or inclination, it is the dominant story . Stories change constantly and it is time to revise the metanarratives that have led us astray. Fortunately, cryptoeconomics is rapidly generating legitimate alternatives to traditional power structures, and [regenerative cryptoeconomics](https://greenpill.party/#book) is enabling win-win-win mechanisms for individuals, communities and the commons.

Daisyworld as a decentralised autonomous organisation (DAO) aims to play a role in regenerating our world. We aim to generate collective imaginations of possible futures and we aim to design funding mechanisms to determine and enable [effective regeneering](https://mirror.xyz/0x7F66d195b3a7747E442C843aC86dea7D88f5B48B/Qr45QfByVU_DR5BBpez9CP0kHJAX7DKBmf6RuJAS1N0).

### Vision

Daisyworld cultivates two things that act in synergy:

1. An environment for [divergent](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780123750389000777) exploration and dialogue to produce collective manifestations of possible futures.
2. A roundtable of [convergence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_thinking) and coordination design using decentralised and [polycentric](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Cz0sL2fFjM&t=1s) governance systems.

### Mission

Generate a maximally effective climate emergency response that is holistic and autopoietic.

### Core value proposition:

Decentralising the deployment of [effective regeneering](https://mirror.xyz/0x7F66d195b3a7747E442C843aC86dea7D88f5B48B/Qr45QfByVU_DR5BBpez9CP0kHJAX7DKBmf6RuJAS1N0) initiatives in order to generate maximal beneficial outcomes (MBOs) is the purpose of Daisyworlds existence.Â This is a vision we can all pursue according to our own unique situations, preferences, motivations and passions.

Regeneering MBOs incorporates subjective and objective accounts of reality. Regeneering is about generating and distributing the [eight forms of capital](http://appleseedpermaculture.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/8_Forms_of_Capital_PM68.pdf) as described by [Appleseed Permaculture](https://www.appleseed.design/).

MBOs are primarily determined using [Warm Data](https://warmdatalab.net/warm-data), which is described as transcontextual information. Traditional data, in contrast, describes only the parts of a system, while Warm Data describes interplay in context. Enabling regeneering initiatives such as [MEER.org](https://www.meer.org/)â€™s [surfaced based solar radiation management strategy](https://www.meer.org/whymeer) involves dramatically altering massive amounts of landscapes. Warm Data will enable an understanding of the affected communitiesâ€™ perspectives, including objections, support and innovations.

Daisyworldâ€™s fundamental belief is that cultivating relationships is paramount in generating an effective regenerative transformation. Daisyworld plans to enable a story-sharing initiative called Mycelium Network Dialogue. Sharing our stories in a safe and respectful atmosphere symbiosis naturally emerges, creating a community of belonging. These conversations will catalyse grassroots support and innovation in regeneering planetary systems.

Daisyworld is but one of many impact DAOs determined to ensure planetary homeostasis.

## Values

* Believing in a vital and beautiful future
* Antifragile Systems Thinking
* Polycentric Pluralism
* Fractal Sovereignty
* The Small Group as a Unit of Transformation
* Interbeing - belonging
* Imagination - Liminal Possibility Questing
* Community
* Intuitive Design
* Beauty + Art + Fun
* Public Goods

## Daisyworlds Four Dimensions

### 1) Funding - Receptor

* Fundraising campaigns building relationships while raising [eight forms of capital](http://appleseedpermaculture.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/8_Forms_of_Capital_PM68.pdf).

### 2) Distribution - Effector

* Collectively designed funding distribution mechanisms enabling effective regeneering

### 3) Token - Petals (PTLS)

* Meaningful money energetically tied to regenerative activities.

### 4) Mycelium Network Dialogue (MND)

* MND is a story-sharing technique enabled by web3 [data sovereignty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_sovereignty)
* MND is a generative substrate for collective intelligence and wisdom.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UyCkFoSIwWg](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UyCkFoSIwWg)

### daisyworld@protonmail.com

Join our telegram group.

[https://t.me/+TWy6tKptQSY5MzBl](https://t.me/+TWy6tKptQSY5MzBl)

![The Power of Group Pertinence is not to be underrated](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Vp4_gvktSvcOr0rkEd6y3.png?height=1392&width=1822)

**The Anthropocene is like a wise old bird stuck in a neo-liberal cage, Daisyworld aims to set it free.**

*This article is a work in progress and is subject to revision. Last revised 12-July-2022.*
